deck: Final incarnation of the British Spider-Man weekly.
description:
The final incarnation of Marvel UK's longest running title, originally called Spider-Man Comics Weekly, and, most recently prior to becoming Spidey Comic as of August 31st 1985, The Spider-Man Comic. By this point the title was mainly aimed at younger readers, and had minimal Marvel universe content. Spider-Man's stories were, in many instances, reprints of Spidey Super Stories, while other pages were filled with reprints of Star Comics' Ewoks, an adaptation of Disney's The Black Cauldron, and Indiana Jones (from Marvel's Further Adventures of Indiana Jones). This bizarre combination was not a strong seller, and Spidey Comics was cancelled on 14th December 1985 with issue 666.

Shortly after this, Spider-Man was relaunched in a new series, Spider-Man and Zoids.
name: Spidey Comic

deck: The story of the origin of the Avengers as it might have been had the creators of Marvel in 1998 been around at the beginning of Marvel Comics.
description:
The origin of the Avengers as it might have been had the "greatest creators" of 1998 been working for Stan Lee at the beginning of Marvel Comics.

NOTE: Indicia titled as "Timeslip Special".
name: Timeslip Special

description:
With sales of Spider-Man dropping, Marvel UK noted that other comics aimed at younger readers were selling strongly and decided to repitch the title at this audience. The Spider-Man stories from the mainstream US titles were replaced, first by the Spider-Man and his Amazing Friends story from the Denver Post free comic, then by reprints of Spidey Super Stories. Other strips included Star Comics' Wally the Wizard (retitled Willy the Wizard in case readers found Wally an unintentionally amusing name, somehow overlooking that Willy had even greater double entendre humour potential) and Fraggle Rock, plus two humour strips from Lew Stringer: Captain Wally and Snail-Man. Dukes of Hazzard, reprinted from Polystyle's TV Comic, was added in #638, and Indiana Jones from Marvel's Further Adventures of Indiana Jones in #646.

With #651 the comic underwent a further, final title change to become Spidey Comic.
name: The Spider-Man Comic

description:
Having most recently gone by the title Spider-Man and His Amazing Friends, seeking to capitalise on the popularity of the cartoon of that name, Marvel UK's longest running title renamed itself simply Spider-Man as of #579, released 11th April 1984. Spider-Man #595 saw the comic absorb failing sister title The Thing is Big Ben, briefly acknowledging this merger on the cover. Spider-Man #607 to #610 featured a new, non-reprint Spider-Man story.

However, a few months later, with sales dropping, the decision was made to refocus the Spider-Man title towards younger readers, and with #634 the series was rebranded as The Spider-Man Comic.
name: Spider-Man

description:
Having previously been titled simply Spider-Man, on October 12th 1983 with #553, Marvel UK's longest running title renamed itself Spider-Man and his Amazing Friends in an attempt to capitalise on the popularity of the cartoon series of that name which was then airing on British TV. After three issues reprinting the US comic adaptation of the cartoon's pilot episode, the ongoing Spider-Man strip reverted to reprinting the regular US Spider-Man titles, but the Amazing Friends subtitle was retained. With #567 on January 18th 1984 the comic absorbed failing sister title Thor and the X-Men, briefly acknowledging the merger on the cover.

The last issue titled Spider-Man and his Amazing Friends was #578; the next issue the comic renamed itself back to just Spider-Man.
name: Spider-Man and his Amazing Friends
Real Love: The Best of Simon and Kirby Romance Comics

description: The Beagle Boys and Beagle Brats are in on another caper.
name: Top Comics Walt Disney The Beagle Boys

name: Thimble Theatre, Starring Popeye Volume Two

description:
Previously titled Super Spider-Man TV Comic in hopes of appealing to fans of the live-action Spider-Man TV show, Marvel UK's longest running title became simply Spider-Man on 6th October 1982 with #500, absorbing the failing Incredible Hulk comic the same week. Spider-Woman rejoined the title with #517 on 2nd February 1983 when her cartoon began airing in the UK, reprinting the same comics which had appeared in Spider-Man and Hulk Weekly (a prior name for Spider-Man) less than three years earlier. Fantastic Four returned to the title with #529 on 27th April 1983, following the cancellation of their own title.

The last issue using the title Spider-Man, for the time being at least, was #552 on 5th October 1983; a week later the comic retitled to Spider-Man and his Amazing Friends.
name: Spider-Man

description:
"Adult Series" collection. Titles:

  1. De Groene Man van het bos (The Green Man of the forest)
  2. Bruce Jones presenteert: Verhalen Uit de schemering (Bruce Jones presents: Stories From the twilight)

  4. Nadia: Het eiland van de Dood (Nadia: The Isle of the Dead)

Bruce Jones presenteert: Verhalen Uit de schemering

description:
Spider-Man and Hulk Team-Up changed its name to Super Spider-Man TV Comic with October 21st 1981's 450th issue, hoping to use interest in the Nicholas Hammond TV series to draw in new readers. With the rebranding came glossy covers and a few extra pages of interior colour.

Just under a year later it rebranded again; #499 was the last for the unwieldy Super Spider-Man TV Comic title, and with #500 on October 6th 1982, the title became simply Spider-Man.
name: Super Spider-Man TV Comic

description:
On March 11th 1981 Spider-Man and Hulk Weekly absorbed fellow Marvel UK title Marvel Team-Up and added its name to the banner, becoming Spider-Man and Hulk Weekly incorporating Marvel Team-Up with #118. With #425, this unwieldy name became the simpler, albeit inaccurate in story terms, Spider-Man and Hulk Team-Up.

However, the airing of the Spider-Man live action TV show on British TV prompted another title change by #450 on October 21st, when the comic was renamed Super Spider-Man TV Comic.
name: Spider-Man and Hulk Team-Up

description:
On May 22nd 1980 with #376 the former Spectacular Spider-Man Weekly absorbed its less successful sister title Incredible Hulk, and renamed itself Spider-Man and Hulk Weekly. Previous back-up strips were dropped in favour of beginning reprint runs of She-Hulk and Spider-Woman, so that the two title stars were appearing alongside their female counterparts.

The new title lasted until #417 on 4th March 1981; a week later Marvel Team-Up was merged into Spider-Man and Hulk Weekly, which renamed itself first Spider-Man and Hulk Weekly incorporating Team-Up and then just Spider-Man and Hulk Team-Up to reflect the new status quo.
name: Spider-Man and Hulk Weekly
Comic Shop News 2012 Spring Preview

description:
On August 1st 1979 the former Spider-Man Comic merged with Marvel Comic to become The Spectacular Spider-Man Weekly and Marvel Comic #334. With #337 the "and Marvel Comic" was dropped, leaving the title just The Spectacular Spider-Man Weekly.

On April 24th 1980, #372 dropped the "Weekly" from the title, but a bigger change was imminent; May 15th 1980's #376 was the last issue to go by the Spectacular title, as a week later Incredible Hulk was merged into Spider-Man's comic, which was renamed Spider-Man and Hulk Weekly.
name: Spectacular Spider-Man Weekly

description: Il Mago was an italian comic and humour magazine. It ran from 1972 to 1980.
name: Il Mago

description:
In January 1979, Marvel UK editor in chief Dez Skinn oversaw an overhaul of the company's comics line. As part of that, the titles for some longer running ongoing weekly comics were simplified: Mighty World of Marvel became just Marvel Comic, and Super Spider-Man was retitled Spider-Man Comic with 24th January's #311.

The new name only lasted a few months. Spider-Man Comic #333, dated July 25th 1981, was the last to use that title, changing a week later to become Spectacular Spider-Man Weekly.
name: Spider-Man Comic

description: With the departure of Captain Britain from its pages, Super Spider-Man and Captain Britain logically renamed itself as just Super Spider-Man as of 21st December 1977 and #254, a title that title remained in place until 17th January 1979's #310. With #311, editor in chief Dez Skinn's move make the weekly titles more aligned with one another started, and this series became Spider-Man Comic.
name: Super Spider-Man

description:
Super Spider-Man with the Super-Heroes absorbed fellow Marvel UK title The Titans on December 1st 1976, and retitled itself Super Spider-Man and the Titans from #199.

Having been printed as a landscape comic since #158 (when Spider-Man Comics Weekly had undergone its first major title change to Super Spider-Man with the Super-Heroes), Spider-Man and the Titans eventually reverted to the more traditional portrait layout with #229, only two issues before another merger, this time with Captain Britain, prompted another name change; #230 was the last issue of Super Spider-Man and the Titans, which became Super Spider-Man and Captain Britain as of #231.
name: Super Spider-Man and the Titans

deck: Preview issue of the limited series Hellina vs Pandora.
description: Preview issue of the limited series Hellina vs Pandora.
name: Hellina vs Pandora Preview

description:
One of Marvel UK's early titles, The Super-Heroes was cancelled on 14th February 1976, and a week later it merged with Spider-Man Comics Weekly, which retitled itself Super Spider-Man with the Super-Heroes as of #158, the merger issue, and adopted a new "landscape" format, whereby the comic was printed longer than it was tall, with each page of the UK comic reprinting two US pages reduced in size and alongside one another.

The final issue of Super Spider-Man with the Super-Heroes was #198; a week later The Titans merged with it, and the comic was renamed Super Spider-Man and the Titans.
name: Super Spider-Man with the Super-Heroes

description:
Spider-Man Comics Weekly was Marvel UK's second title (the first being Mighty World of Marvel) and would go on to be its longest running, albeit under several different names during its twelve year run. The first issue, dated 17th February 1873, featured Spider-Man, fresh from appearing in MWoM, and Thor, and it wasn't until #50 that another strip, Iron Man, joined the title.

For the first three years of publication Spider-Man Comics Weekly was a stable title, but major changes were on their way. #157 would be the last to go by the original name, as cancelled title The Super-Heroes was merged into Spider-Man Comics Weekly from #158, which was accordingly retitled Super Spider-Man with the Super-Heroes.
name: Spider-Man Comics Weekly

description: Like the other two Fleetway Super Libraries (Fantastic/Stupendous and Secret Agent series), the Front Line series ran from January 1967 to January 1968, two issue per month with alternating stars, for a total of 13 adventures each and 26 issues in total. In the Front Line Series' case, both strips were World War II adventures. The Maddock's Marauders half of the run featured the missions of Captain Matt Maddock's small international unit of soldiers, while the other half followed the US Army's Sergeant Ironsides, a stereotypical tough-as-nails wartime hero. Both series transferred to Battle Picture Library when Front Line ended, and enjoyed further adventures through to the mid-1970s.
name: Fleetway Super Library Front Line Series

description: Like the other two Fleetway Super Libraries (Front Line and Secret Agent series), the Stupendous Series ran from January 1967 to January 1968, two issue per month with alternating stars, for a total of 13 adventures each and 26 issues in total. In this series case, the two alternating leads were Valiant's Steel Claw and Lion's Spider. The first two issues were titled Fantastic Series, but retitled, perhaps to avoid trademark issues with Odham's Fantastic comic.
name: Fleetway Super Library Stupendous Series

deck: Collection of stories from Air Ace
description: When War Picture Library was launched in 1958 it quickly became apparent that many of the most popular stories with the readers featured the adventures of the warriors of the air, pilots who soared and swooped through the sky, cannons and machine guns blazing. The flyers were seen as the glamour boys of the Second World War, handling the most sophisticated and technically advanced combat machines ever invented and there was almost limitless scope to develop stories based around their exploits. The machines that they flew—fighters such as Spitfires, Hurricanes, Messerschmitts, Mustangs and Zeros—were lovingly recreated by the finest artists, in the brand new Air Ace Picture Library in 1960. Those images are reproduced here 25 per cent larger than in their original published form, pulling you into close formation in the thick of the action. The ten stories in "Aces High" take you from the flak-blasted night sky over Germany to the sweltering heat of the tropics, twisting and turning like a Typhoon with a Focke Wolf in its sights!
name: Aces High

issues.name: The 10 Best Air Ace Picture Library Comic Books Ever!

first_issue.name: The 10 Best Air Ace Picture Library Comic Books Ever!

last_issue.name: The 10 Best Air Ace Picture Library Comic Books Ever!

description:
A weekly comedy/horror themed comic from IPC, Monster Fun began publication on 14th June 1975.

One of its best attributes was the small pull out comic in the centre pages called the Badtime Bedtime story book. This consisted of eight pages and usually drawn by Leo Baxendale, with titles like Moby Duck, Little Bo Creep, Punch & Chewday, Jack the Nipper's School Days.

The nominal editor was Ken Reid's Frankie Stein, previously one of the characters who had appeared in Wham! (in keeping with a meme of the time for having comic strip characters presented to the readers as editor of the comics, cf. Captain Hurricane in Battle Picture Weekly, Starlord in Starlord, Big E in Tornado, Ghastly McNasty in Scream, Mrs. Bruin in Rainbow, and, most famously, 2000 AD's editor Tharg). Monster Fun lasted just over a year, cancelling with its 73rd issue on 30th October 1976, after which it merged into Buster. Despite this relatively short run, it also enjoyed nine annuals, cover dated 1977 through 1985, plus two Summer Specials, 1975 and 1976, pre-merger, and seventeen, 1976 through 1995, after the merger.
name: Monster Fun

description: These are reissues of the origional1953 10-cent movie edition. The cover illustration is the same, the titles are different. The plot follows the story of the Disney movie version: Wendy, John, and Michael Darling follow Peter Pan to Neverland for a series of adventures with pirates and Indians, then return home to London.
name: Walt Disney Presents Peter Pan

description: In 1979 Purnell published a single tie-in volume to the TV show Worzel Gummidge. Though not officially called an annual, it used the standard format for UK annuals, released in hardback with a mixture of stories and features. World Distributors subsequently won the Worzel Gummidge license and went on to produce several official annuals.
name: Worzel Gummidge

description:
In 1979 World Distributors won the license to produce tie-in annuals to the TV show Worzel Gummidge, and proceeded to publish six annuals from 1979 to 1984 (Annuals 1980 to 1985).

Preceeded by a single Worzel Gummidge book published by Purnell, an annual in all but name.
name: Worzel Gummidge Annual

description: Fleetway published four tie-in annuals to the children's TV show Metal Mickey between 1981 and 1984.
name: Metal Mickey Annual

description: Produced by Innovative Communications, Triffik! was a British weekly comic that was intended to appeal to modern kids more than existing fare such as the Beano. It launched with extremely optimistic sales expectations and correspondingly expensive publicity and costly high print runs, and died a quick death after only twelve issues.
name: Triffik!

description:
"2 comics in 1...double the fun...Shake is inside Shiver!"

So proclaimed the tag line of IPC's Shiver and Shake, launched on 10th March 1973. Like its contemprary, Whizzer and Chips, Shiver and Shake portrayed itself as two titles, with Shake, a fairly traditional British humour comic, presented as a pull-out section inside Shiver, a horror humour oriented comic. The names Shiver and Shake were likewise borrowed, from two ghosts who had appeared in strips in Cor!!, though Shiver, who had been a ghostly cavalier skewered by a phantom blade, became a portly "sheet" ghost who starred in The Duke's Spook inside the Shiver section of the new comic, while Shake, who had originally been a portly sheet ghost virtually identical to the one now called Shiver, became an anthropomorphic elephant who starred in his own namesake strip in the Shake section of the comic. The Shiver section also made good use of two horrific stars of past comics, Grimly Feendish, who had begun life as the antagonist in Eagle-Eye Junior Spy's strip in Wham!, and Frankie Stein, likewise from Wham!, who would eventually supplant Shiver and Shake as the comic's cover star. Each issue also included a Creepy Creatures illustration on the back page, with artist Ken Reid illustrating monsters described by readers' letters. A strike in 1974 meant Shiver and Shake wasn't published in July of that year, skipping four issues, but production resumed in August 1974, only for the title to be cancelled in October 1974. It was absorbed into Whoopee!, but continued to have both annuals, released from 1973 to 1985, and holiday specials, released between 1973 and 1980, despite this cancellation.

Numbering note

As no issue numbers were printed on the comic (unless you count the Creepy Creatures, which were numbered), issues are numbered below in the format YEAR, MONTH, DATE. Thus the final issue, #741008 is 8th October 1974.
name: Shiver and Shake

description: Prior to launching Frantic as an ongoing title in 1980, Marvel UK tested the water with two specials in 1979, a Summer one in May and Winter one in October.
name: Frantic Special

description: De Moker was a Dutch Beeldromans, a "picture paper" produced cheaply post-World War II, using smaller pages than might be found in American or British comics due to post-war paper shortages. Written and drawn by Hans Ducro, the titular De Moker ("the Sledgehammer") was a Dutch superhero. Nine issues were published, all in 1948.
name: De Moker
